LOTlib.Examples.SchemeProgramInduction package¶

Submodules¶

LOTlib.Examples.SchemeProgramInduction.SchemeFunctionLearn module¶

A LOTlib example for bound variables.

This does inference over cons, cdr, car expressions. NOTE: it does not work very well for complex functions since it is hard to sample a close function – not much of a gradient to climb on cons, cdr, car

LOTlib.Examples.SchemeProgramInduction.SchemeGenerate module¶

This generates random scheme code with cons, cdr, and car, and evaluates it on some simple list structures. No inference here–just random sampling from a grammar.

LOTlib.Examples.SchemeProgramInduction.Shared module¶

class LOTlib.Examples.SchemeProgramInduction.Shared.SchemeFunction(grammar, value=None, f=None, start='START', ALPHA=0.9, maxnodes=25, args=['x'], proposal_function=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: LOTlib.Hypotheses.LOTHypothesis.LOTHypothesis

compute_single_likelihood(datum)[source]¶

Wrap in string for comparisons here. Also, this is a weird pseudo-likelihood (an outlier process) since when we are wrong, it should generate the observed data with some probability that’s not going to be 1-ALPHA
